update.description:
Implement Bullet plugin for physics simulation.

Requires [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/403](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/403).

Current features support running:

* `shapes.sdf`
* `world_joint.sdf`
* `diff_drive.sdf`
* `apply_joint_force.sdf`
* `quadcopter.sdf`

Some previous discussion in [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/97](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/97).

‌

Note:

1\. Current implementation is not optimized for efficiency yet.

2\. Tests not complete.

3\. Behavior for car\_collision.sdf example might be different between Bullet 2.87 and 2.88.
update.title: [WIP] Add Bullet physics engine

content.raw:
I've made a pull request to ign-cmake that adds `FindIgnBullet.cmake`:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/162/add-findignbullet-cmake-module/diff

This find module can be used with the following patches:

~~~
diff -r b8da443c8e78 CMakeLists.txt
--- a/CMakeLists.txt    Tue Aug 13 17:31:57 2019 -0700
+++ b/CMakeLists.txt    Tue Aug 13 17:33:46 2019 -0700
@@ -73,12 +73,11 @@
 
 #--------------------------------------
 # Find bullet for the bullet plugin wrapper
-include(FindPkgConfig)
-
-pkg_check_modules(BULLET bullet>=2.87 REQUIRED)
-if (NOT BULLET_FOUND)
-    pkg_check_modules(BULLET bullet2.87>=2.87)
-endif()
+ign_find_package(IgnBullet
+  VERSION 2.87
+  REQUIRED_BY bullet
+  PKGCONFIG bullet
+  PKGCONFIG_VER_COMPARISON >=)
 
 message(STATUS "-------------------------------------------\n")
 
diff -r b8da443c8e78 bullet/CMakeLists.txt
--- a/bullet/CMakeLists.txt     Tue Aug 13 17:31:57 2019 -0700
+++ b/bullet/CMakeLists.txt     Tue Aug 13 17:33:46 2019 -0700
@@ -5,9 +5,7 @@
   GET_TARGET_NAME features)
 
 link_directories(${BULLET_LIBRARY_DIRS})
-target_link_libraries(${features} INTERFACE ${BULLET_LIBRARIES})
-target_include_directories(${features} SYSTEM INTERFACE ${BULLET_INCLUDE_DIRS})
-add_definitions(${BULLET_CFLAGS})
+target_link_libraries(${features} INTERFACE IgnBullet)
 
 ign_get_libsources_and_unittests(sources test_sources)
 
~~~
content.html:
I've made a pull request to ign-cmake that adds FindIgnBullet.cmake:

  • #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/162/add-findignbullet-cmake-module/diff

This find module can be used with the following patches:

diff -r b8da443c8e78 CMakeLists.txt
--- a/CMakeLists.txt    Tue Aug 13 17:31:57 2019 -0700
+++ b/CMakeLists.txt    Tue Aug 13 17:33:46 2019 -0700
@@ -73,12 +73,11 @@

 #--------------------------------------
 # Find bullet for the bullet plugin wrapper
-include(FindPkgConfig)
-
-pkg_check_modules(BULLET bullet>=2.87 REQUIRED)
-if (NOT BULLET_FOUND)
-    pkg_check_modules(BULLET bullet2.87>=2.87)
-endif()
+ign_find_package(IgnBullet
+  VERSION 2.87
+  REQUIRED_BY bullet
+  PKGCONFIG bullet
+  PKGCONFIG_VER_COMPARISON >=)

 message(STATUS "-------------------------------------------\n")

diff -r b8da443c8e78 bullet/CMakeLists.txt
--- a/bullet/CMakeLists.txt     Tue Aug 13 17:31:57 2019 -0700
+++ b/bullet/CMakeLists.txt     Tue Aug 13 17:33:46 2019 -0700
@@ -5,9 +5,7 @@
   GET_TARGET_NAME features)

 link_directories(${BULLET_LIBRARY_DIRS})
-target_link_libraries(${features} INTERFACE ${BULLET_LIBRARIES})
-target_include_directories(${features} SYSTEM INTERFACE ${BULLET_INCLUDE_DIRS})
-add_definitions(${BULLET_CFLAGS})
+target_link_libraries(${features} INTERFACE IgnBullet)

 ign_get_libsources_and_unittests(sources test_sources)

The bullet plugin has now been updated to construct models directly from a complete `sdf::Model`. The dependent pull request  [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/403](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/403) has been updated as well.

`FinalizeModels` feature has been removed.

This should resolve the concerns.

content.raw: yes, it would be nice if `ign-gazebo` only needed `ConstructSdfModel`; that would make things easier for some physics engines (like bullet in this case)
content.html: yes, it would be nice if ign-gazebo only needed ConstructSdfModel; that would make things easier for some physics engines (like bullet in this case)

content.raw:
> or have ign-gazebo store the original sdf::Model element in a component that ign-gazebo can lookup later.

I think the main issue that prevented us from storing an `sdf::Model` in a component is that a lot of the SDF DOM objects did not have copy constructors and so it wasn't possible to create a copy of `sdf::Model` from children of `sdf::World`. I believe this is now [fixed](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/524/).
content.html:
or have ign-gazebo store the original sdf::Model element in a component that ign-gazebo can lookup later.

I think the main issue that prevented us from storing an sdf::Model in a component is that a lot of the SDF DOM objects did not have copy constructors and so it wasn't possible to create a copy of sdf::Model from children of sdf::World. I believe this is now fixed.

content.raw:
> we would want `sdf::Model` to have complete information of its links, joints and etc., so that the whole model could be constructed in a single call

Correct, and I think ordinarily that's how sdformat is meant to be used, where the `sdf::Model` has complete information about its `sdf::Link` and `sdf::Joint` members.

> I don't think it has access to the sdf element pointer in `ign-gazebo` physics system when it was being constructed

Based on [CreatePhysicsEntities](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/4b23bd2fe9c304c655ca15c047725d7f91b9bba1/src/systems/physics/Physics.cc#lines-299) it seems you're right: the SDF entities that get passed to the `ConstructSdf*`  functions are minimal and created on the fly based on model, link, and joint components. And you're also right that because of limitations in sdformat's API, it's not possible to aggregate all that data into a single `sdf::Model` instance without reconstructing an equivalent `sdf::Element` instance.

In my view this is an abuse of how sdformat is designed to be used. To me that suggests that we should either:

1. Rework the design of sdformat to allow users to explicitly insert links, joints, etc into their parent objects, and then have `ign-gazebo` aggregate all the information into an `sdf::Model` instance
2. or have `ign-gazebo` store the original `sdf::Model` element in a component that `ign-gazebo` can lookup later.

I would lean heavily towards the second option, because that would be the most straightforward way for physics engine plugins to support custom sdformat fields \(like the `<ode>` and `<bullet>` tags.
content.html:
we would want sdf::Model to have complete information of its links, joints and etc., so that the whole model could be constructed in a single call

Correct, and I think ordinarily that's how sdformat is meant to be used, where the sdf::Model has complete information about its sdf::Link and sdf::Joint members.

I don't think it has access to the sdf element pointer in ign-gazebo physics system when it was being constructed

Based on CreatePhysicsEntities it seems you're right: the SDF entities that get passed to the ConstructSdf* functions are minimal and created on the fly based on model, link, and joint components. And you're also right that because of limitations in sdformat's API, it's not possible to aggregate all that data into a single sdf::Model instance without reconstructing an equivalent sdf::Element instance.

In my view this is an abuse of how sdformat is designed to be used. To me that suggests that we should either:

  1. Rework the design of sdformat to allow users to explicitly insert links, joints, etc into their parent objects, and then have ign-gazebo aggregate all the information into an sdf::Model instance
  2. or have ign-gazebo store the original sdf::Model element in a component that ign-gazebo can lookup later.

I would lean heavily towards the second option, because that would be the most straightforward way for physics engine plugins to support custom sdformat fields (like the <ode> and <bullet> tags.

content.raw: :blush: No problem, I like working on this!
content.html: No problem, I like working on this!

content.raw:
Hi Grey, calling `btMultiBody::finalizeMultiDof()` multiple times was fine. I added `FinalizeModels` for two reasons:

* Changing the number of links after having created `btMultiBody` gave errors. In other words, I had to know the number of links a model has before initializing the model. However, I had just looked further into it, and it turned out to be a bug in Bullet. A fix has also been merged, but that only exists in the `master` branch at the moment.
* When constructing a joint that attaches a link to the fixed world frame, I would set the `btMultiBody` to have fixed base, and attach the joint between link and base. Otherwise `btMultiBody` would have floating base by default. I need to set whether fixed base when initializing `btMultiBody`, but wouldn’t get this information until all joints have been added.

With the above requirements, I then decided to lump everything together and construct `btMultiBody` with the `FinalizeModels` call in the end when the information was complete. I didn't like it either, since it deviates from the original flow of model construction in `ign-physics`. But that seemed to be the only way I could implement bullet plugin, so I just went with it.

‌

As for not supporting `ConstructSdfLink()`, `ConstructSdfJoint()` and etc., I think that makes sense but I have two questions:

* In that case, when we pass `sdf::Model` to `ConstructSdfModel()`, we would want `sdf::Model` to have complete information of its links, joints and etc., so that the whole model could be constructed in a single call. I think that is what you are suggesting? But `sdf::Model` has no way of setting them, apart from its `Load(ElementPtr _sdf)`function, but I don't think it has access to the sdf element pointer in `ign-gazebo` physics system when it was being constructed.
* I haven't yet figured out how to use optional features when using `ign-physics`. Currently in `ign-gazebo` physics system, if the plugin does not pass the `MinimumFeatureList`, it wouldn't be loaded. But I don’t know how do I specify optional feature list, or call functions not in the `MinimumFeatureList`.
content.html:
Hi Grey, calling btMultiBody::finalizeMultiDof() multiple times was fine. I added FinalizeModels for two reasons:

  • Changing the number of links after having created btMultiBody gave errors. In other words, I had to know the number of links a model has before initializing the model. However, I had just looked further into it, and it turned out to be a bug in Bullet. A fix has also been merged, but that only exists in the master branch at the moment.
  • When constructing a joint that attaches a link to the fixed world frame, I would set the btMultiBody to have fixed base, and attach the joint between link and base. Otherwise btMultiBody would have floating base by default. I need to set whether fixed base when initializing btMultiBody, but wouldn’t get this information until all joints have been added.

With the above requirements, I then decided to lump everything together and construct btMultiBody with the FinalizeModels call in the end when the information was complete. I didn't like it either, since it deviates from the original flow of model construction in ign-physics. But that seemed to be the only way I could implement bullet plugin, so I just went with it.

‌

As for not supporting ConstructSdfLink(), ConstructSdfJoint() and etc., I think that makes sense but I have two questions:

  • In that case, when we pass sdf::Model to ConstructSdfModel(), we would want sdf::Model to have complete information of its links, joints and etc., so that the whole model could be constructed in a single call. I think that is what you are suggesting? But sdf::Model has no way of setting them, apart from its Load(ElementPtr _sdf)function, but I don't think it has access to the sdf element pointer in ign-gazebo physics system when it was being constructed.
  • I haven't yet figured out how to use optional features when using ign-physics. Currently in ign-gazebo physics system, if the plugin does not pass the MinimumFeatureList, it wouldn't be loaded. But I don’t know how do I specify optional feature list, or call functions not in the MinimumFeatureList.

content.raw:
I have some concerns about the `FinalizeModels` function for two reasons:

* In OOP, it's best to avoid patterns where objects may have "incomplete" states. That means avoiding member functions like `init()` and `finalize()` \(I know these kinds of functions are being used in other ignition libraries currently, but I consider that to be baggage which we've managed to avoid in `ignition-physics`\)
* The need to "finalize" a model is based on an implementation detail of Bullet, but that requirement is being pushed up to `ignition-physics` in this PR. A goal of `ignition-physics` is to avoid the situation where implementation details of physics engines are dictating the end user’s experience.

Instead I recommend we use the [builder pattern](https://cpppatterns.com/patterns/builder.html). This means that we would build up a description of a model in a "builder" object, and then hand that builder object to some member function of the `Model` class once the description is complete.

We actually have an effective builder pattern already thanks to the function `ignition::physics::sdf::ConstructSdfModel(~)`. The `sdf::Model` class can be thought of as the builder class in that context.

This brings me to a question about how bullet works: Is it possible to call `btMultiBody::finalizeMultiDof()` multiple times on the same `btMultiBody` object?

* If so, we can support incremental building \(like `ConstructSdfLink()`, `ConstructSdfJoint()` by re-finalizing the `btMultiBody` at the end of each of those function calls.
* If not, we should consider **not supporting** incremental building for the bullet plugin by simply not including `sdf::ConstructSdfLink` and `sdf::ConstructSdfJoint` in the feature set of the bullet plugin. One of the design goals of `ignition-physics` is to make it so that not all plugins need to support all features.
content.html:
I have some concerns about the FinalizeModels function for two reasons:

  • In OOP, it's best to avoid patterns where objects may have "incomplete" states. That means avoiding member functions like init() and finalize() (I know these kinds of functions are being used in other ignition libraries currently, but I consider that to be baggage which we've managed to avoid in ignition-physics)
  • The need to "finalize" a model is based on an implementation detail of Bullet, but that requirement is being pushed up to ignition-physics in this PR. A goal of ignition-physics is to avoid the situation where implementation details of physics engines are dictating the end user’s experience.

Instead I recommend we use the builder pattern. This means that we would build up a description of a model in a "builder" object, and then hand that builder object to some member function of the Model class once the description is complete.

We actually have an effective builder pattern already thanks to the function ignition::physics::sdf::ConstructSdfModel(~). The sdf::Model class can be thought of as the builder class in that context.

This brings me to a question about how bullet works: Is it possible to call btMultiBody::finalizeMultiDof() multiple times on the same btMultiBody object?

  • If so, we can support incremental building (like ConstructSdfLink(), ConstructSdfJoint() by re-finalizing the btMultiBody at the end of each of those function calls.
  • If not, we should consider not supporting incremental building for the bullet plugin by simply not including sdf::ConstructSdfLink and sdf::ConstructSdfJoint in the feature set of the bullet plugin. One of the design goals of ignition-physics is to make it so that not all plugins need to support all features.

content.raw: On another note, it's really great to see someone using `ignition-physics` to wrap a whole new physics engine. Thanks for tackling this huge task, @{5ced8302f0a52d0f240650f8} !
content.html: On another note, it's really great to see someone using ignition-physics to wrap a whole new physics engine. Thanks for tackling this huge task, @Jay Li !

content.raw: As far as I see now, there is not much difference. Either calling `Engine::FinalizeModels` once or calling `Model::Finalize` for each model should work.
content.html: As far as I see now, there is not much difference. Either calling Engine::FinalizeModels once or calling Model::Finalize for each model should work.

update.description:
Implement Bullet plugin for physics simulation.

Requires [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/403](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/403).

Current features support running:

* `shapes.sdf`
* `world_joint.sdf`
* `diff_drive.sdf`
* `apply_joint_force.sdf`
* `quadcopter.sdf`

Some previous discussion in [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/97](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/97).

‌

Note:

1\. Current implementation is not optimized for efficiency yet.

2\. Tests not yet added.
update.title: [WIP] Add Bullet physics engine

content.raw: I think our experiences have made it pretty clear that `FindIgnBullet.cmake` is the right way to go, to avoid painful and confusing conflicts with other find-modules or config-files that might pop up in the future.
content.html: I think our experiences have made it pretty clear that FindIgnBullet.cmake is the right way to go, to avoid painful and confusing conflicts with other find-modules or config-files that might pop up in the future.

content.raw: do you have a  preference between `FindBullet.cmake` and `FindIgnBullet.cmake`?
content.html: do you have a preference between FindBullet.cmake and FindIgnBullet.cmake?

content.raw: Yep, that way we can use `ign_find_package(~)` and all the package config info can be automatically generated.
content.html: Yep, that way we can use ign_find_package(~) and all the package config info can be automatically generated.

content.raw:
I used raw pointers because all the examples in Bullet I saw used them directly, which made it more straightforward to imitate.

Do you think shared pointers might work? If so I will definitely try that.
content.html:
I used raw pointers because all the examples in Bullet I saw used them directly, which made it more straightforward to imitate.

Do you think shared pointers might work? If so I will definitely try that.

content.raw:
Yes exactly!

But it seemed okay to call `finalizeMultiDof` repeatedly, as far as I had tried.

The main reason I added `sdf/FinalizeModels` feature is to know the total number of links for a model before calling `new btMultiBody()`, since changing `numLinks` afterwards gave segmentation errors even though `btMultiBody` has a function named `setNumLinks`.
content.html:
Yes exactly!

But it seemed okay to call finalizeMultiDof repeatedly, as far as I had tried.

The main reason I added sdf/FinalizeModels feature is to know the total number of links for a model before calling new btMultiBody(), since changing numLinks afterwards gave segmentation errors even though btMultiBody has a function named setNumLinks.

content.raw:
The new sdf/FinalizeModels feature needs some documentation. It looks like the feature is based on the `finalizeMultiDof` function in bullet that was added in the following PR:

* https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/pull/337/files#diff-310d1cfc127b12e6cc3b0d510dba7b60

I'm guessing this is a function that needs to be called after all sdf Construct functions have been called and before a btMultiBody model can be used?
content.html:
The new sdf/FinalizeModels feature needs some documentation. It looks like the feature is based on the finalizeMultiDof function in bullet that was added in the following PR:

  • https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/pull/337/files#diff-310d1cfc127b12e6cc3b0d510dba7b60

I'm guessing this is a function that needs to be called after all sdf Construct functions have been called and before a btMultiBody model can be used?
